message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The described deformity is consistent with congenital talipes equinovarus (clubfoot) and repositioning and serial casting is the most appropriate next step in management according to current treatment guidelines. Foot abduction brace and physiotherapy can also be used after serial casting but they are not the immediate next step. Surgery is considered only in severe cases that do not respond to conservative treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The described deformity is consistent with congenital talipes equinovarus, commonly known as clubfoot. The most appropriate management is repositioning and serial casting, which involves gentle manipulation and straightening of the feet followed by casting in a corrected position. Surgery may be considered if conservative measures fail, but it is not the first-line treatment. Foot abduction brace and physiotherapy are not sufficient as standalone treatments for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn has congenital clubfoot, which is best managed with repositioning and serial casting. Surgery is a last resort if conservative measures fail. A foot abduction brace and physiotherapy are not the first line of treatment for congenital clubfoot.

We refer to Mayo Clinic articles on medicine for help. The description of the foot deformity is consistent with clubfoot. Repositioning and serial casting is the most appropriate next step in management as it has been shown to be effective in correcting the deformity in the majority of cases. Foot abduction brace, surgery, and physiotherapy may be used in addition to casting if needed, but they are not the initial management of choice.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The described deformity is consistent with congenital talipes equinovarus, also known as clubfoot. Repositioning and serial casting is the standard treatment for clubfoot, and is recommended as the most appropriate next step in management. Surgery is reserved for cases that are resistant to casting or those with a more severe form of the deformity. Foot abduction braces and physiotherapy are not the recommended first-line treatments for clubfoot.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description suggests that the baby has congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV), also known as clubfoot. Repositioning and serial casting is the most appropriate initial management for CTEV. A foot abduction brace may be used in follow-up treatment after initial casting. Surgery is reserved for more severe cases or cases that do not respond to initial treatment. Physiotherapy does not address the underlying deformity and is not the most appropriate next step.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the foot deformity suggests that the newborn has clubfoot or talipes equinovarus. The most appropriate next step is repositioning and serial casting, which involves gently stretching the feet and holding them in place with casts. This method is effective in correcting the deformity in most cases. Surgery is a last resort if other methods fail, and physiotherapy alone is not sufficient to correct the deformity. Foot abduction brace may be used as a part of the serial casting process.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the foot deformity suggests congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV), also known as clubfoot. The initial management for CTEV is repositioning and serial casting, which helps stretch the contracted tendons and ligaments in the foot. Foot abduction brace is used for maintenance after casting, surgery is generally not recommended as initial treatment, and physiotherapy alone is not sufficient to correct the deformity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the deformity suggests that the newborn has congenital clubfoot. The most appropriate next step in management is repositioning and serial casting, which is the standard non-surgical treatment for clubfoot. Foot abduction brace may be used after correction, surgery is reserved for severe cases, and physiotherapy alone is not sufficient to correct the deformity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the deformity suggests a congenital clubfoot. The most appropriate next step in the management of this patient would be repositioning and serial casting to gradually correct the deformity. Surgery is reserved for cases where casting fails. Physiotherapy may be useful in the rehabilitation phase after the deformity has been corrected. A foot abduction brace is not the first-line treatment for congenital clubfoot.
